_prev_prog_3.Description:
This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program. This program is intended to be a living document. As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Family Tree Farms has elected to use PSMWriter software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling and tracking RMP-PSM related activities.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Family Tree Farms has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 Family Tree Farms, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Family Tree Farms has updated their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following process which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name               | Process Chemical               | Process Quantity(lbs.)

Ammonia Refrigeration        Anhydrous Ammonia                20,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses and physical property damage.



Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM plan to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well

2. r

ganized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Description



1.2.1 Facility Layout



Family Tree Farms operates a packing and cold storage facility stone fruit and blueberries in Reedley, CA. The facility has an ammonia refrigeration system that provides refrigeration capacity to the following:

(4) Cold Rooms

(1) Refrigerated Packing Area



1.2.2 Refrigeration System Equipment



The refrigerated spaces are equipped with air-cooling evaporators and accumulators, as required for flooded operation.

Most control valve groups are located on the roof to provide easy access. The refrigeration machinery is contained within or directly outside the machinery room. A partial list of system components includes: 



Machinery Room

(4) Screw compressors

(5) Oil separators

(4) Shell and tube oil coolers

(1) Shell and tube heat exchanger (Abandoned)

(1) Liquid transfer vessel

(1) Main suction accumulator

(1) Thermosyphon vessel

Condenser Area

(3) Evaporative condensers

(1) High pressure receiver

Refrigerated Packing Area (previously Room 5 equipment, walls removed in 2018)

(1) Accumulator

(2) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)

Room 6

(3) Accumulators

(5) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, plate fin)

Room 7

(2) Accumulators

(5) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)

Room 8

(2) Accumulators

(5) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)

Room 9

(2) Accumulators

(5) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)



1.2.3 Process Chemistry



The refrigeration system employed at Family Tree Farms is a flooded system. In this system, high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped to mu

ltiple accumulators. Each accumulator is equipped with an expansion valve which expands the high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure liquid as it enters the accumulator. Each accumulator feeds multiple bunker mounted evaporator coils located in the Cold Storage Rooms and Packing Area. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporator uses an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it travels back to the accumulators, through a suction return line, and into the main suction accumulator. Any remaining liquid falls to the bottom of the vessel and is fed by gravity into the transfer vessel. Inside the transfer vessel, the liquid rises in temperature and is returned to the high pressure receiver as high pressure liquid. From the main suction accumulator, the remaining low pressure vapor is piped to the suction inlet on the screw compressors.



The compressors compress the low pressure vapor, and it exits through the discharge outlet as a high pressure and high temperature vapor. The vapor is then sent to the evaporative condensers where it is cooled and liquefied. The condensers use air and water to cool the warm ammonia as it passes through a series of tubes within the condensers. As the cooling medium of air and water draws the heat from the vapor, the refrigerant condenses into a liquid and flows to the high pressure receiver. The receiver serves as a holding tank for the liquid refrigerant being fed to the low side, and holds the bulk of the refrigerant in the system when it is not operating. This system is also equipped with a thermosyphon vessel located between the evaporative condensers

Low Pressure Control Valve



Opening Valve #1 will evacuate the process through the high pressure side of the system.  Opening Valve #2 will evacuate the process through the low pressure side of the system.  Opening Valve #3 will equalize the high and low pressure portions of the system.



The Emergency Control Box (ECB) is seldom used in a refrigeration system, but has been installed for rare emergency situations.



Each screw compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment.



All ASME pressure vessels and positive displacement compressors are equipped with pressure relief valves designed to relieve pressure and protect the equipment from rupturing. The relief valves on the high side of the system relieve at 250 or 300 psig while the low side of the system relieves at 150 psig. All pressure relief valves are piped to vent to the atmosphere.



Select relief valve assemblies are equipped with a relief vent indicator (RVI) to assist in recognizing that an overpressure event has occurred. Indicator flags are mounted to the shaft of the RVI on the outside of the housing. A paddle is set such that any sudden flow in the relief vent line pushes it down simultaneously raising the flags which then provide a clear signal that a relief valve has lifted. Stoppers mounted to the exterior prevent the flag/shaft from rotating more than the 90? swing.



The Main Suction Accumulator is equipped with a High Level Float Switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressor.

1.2.5 Process Classification

The ammonia refrigeration system at Family Tree Farms consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. As such, the refrigeration system at Family Tree Farms is treated as a single process.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged

and high pressure receiver. The thermosyphon vessel supplies the screw compressor oil coolers with small amounts of high pressure liquid. As this liquid absorbs the heat from the oil, it evaporates inside the oil cooler, and returns to the thermosyphon vessel.



1.2.4 Safety Systems



The machinery room is equipped with two (2) ammonia detectors. One provides low concentration detection and alerts facility personnel and Cold Storage Technologies (CST) if the ammonia concentration exceeds 50 ppm. Audible and visual alarms will be initiated inside and outside the machinery room. In addition, a train horn will activate alerting personnel throughout the facility. A high-level detector is set at 7,5000 ppm and will shut down all refrigeration machinery inside the refrigeration machinery room, and activate an audible alarm and strobe. If the concentration reaches 25 ppm, the emergency ventilation system will kick in.



Each cold room is equipped with one (1) ammonia detector. The Room 5/Packing Area has two (2) ammonia detectors. One on the east side and one on the west side. Each detector alerts facility personnel and Cold Storage Technologies (CST) if the ammonia concentration exceeds 50 ppm. Audible and visual alarms will be initiated inside each room. In addition, a train horn will activate alerting personnel throughout the facility. Each zone will shut down the liquid feed solenoid and the circulating fans if the ammonia concentration exceeds 75 ppm.

The machinery room is equipped with a roof-mounted emergency ventilation fan that automatically activates at 25 ppm. The emergency ventilation system can be controlled manually by the LOW/OFF/HI switch located outside adjacent to the principal machinery room door.



The Emergency Control Box was installed in accordance with ANSI/IIAR 2 and the Fire Code at the time of construction.  The control box contains three (3) valves.

Valve #1: High Side Discharge Valve

Valve #2: Low Side Discharge Valve

Valve #3: High to

in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meetings we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Family Tree Farms has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration process at the Family Tree Farms facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. The ammonia process contains a total charge of approximately 20,000 lbs. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 



1.4 Five Year Accident History



Family Tree Farms has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Family Tree Farms' emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

California "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 8 CCR ?3220

Federal "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38 



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local

Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Family Tree Farms has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Family Tree Farms continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Family Tree Farms' ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Family Tree Farms' management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.



Family Tree Farms has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Family Tree Farms has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.

For the future, Family Tree Farms now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Family Tree Farms employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Family Tree Farms will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
